name: Alon–Saks–Seymour conjecture
summary: In the early 1990s, Noga Alon, Michael Saks, and Paul Seymour developed a conjecture that, if correct, would greatly expand the Graham–Pollak theorem: they postulated that at least k subgraphs are required whenever the edges of a graph with chromatic number k+1 are divided into complete bipartite subgraphs. Similarly, they postulate that at most k+1 colors can always be used to color edge-disjoint unions of k complete bipartite graphs. By creating families of graphs that are edge-disjoint unions of k complete bipartite graphs that require {\displaystyle \Omega (k^{6/5})} colors, Huang and Sudakov refuted the conjecture in 2012.[9] More significantly, up to the {\displaystyle o(1)} term in the exponent, the number of colors can be as great as {\displaystyle \exp \log ^{2-o(1)}k}.[10]
references: Huang, Hao; Sudakov, Benny (2012), "A counterexample to the Alon–Saks–Seymour conjecture and related problems", Combinatorica, 32 (2): 205–219, arXiv:1002.4687, doi:10.1007/s00493-012-2746-4, MR 2927639

Balodis, Kaspars; Ben-David, Shalev; Göös, Mika; Jain, Siddhartha; Kothari, Robin (2021), "Unambiguous DNFs and Alon–Saks–Seymour", 62nd IEEE Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science, FOCS 2021, Denver, CO, USA, February 7-10, 2022, pp. 116–124, arXiv:2102.08348, doi:10.1109/FOCS52979.2021.00020, ISBN 978-1-6654-2055-6
